Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: An upcoming holiday is near, and the children still need to learn the related blessings.
Story:
I sit at the kitchen table, the scent of my mother’s brisket filling the air, as my father reminds me how important it is to keep our family traditions alive. “You know how much it means to your grandmother when we all say the blessings together,” he says, his eyes gentle but firm. I nod, feeling the weight of his words. As a son, I want to honor my parents, to show them that their traditions matter to me, that I am part of this family’s story.

But as a Jew, I know I have another responsibility now. My own children are growing, and the upcoming holiday is just days away. They still don’t know the blessings, haven’t learned the melodies or the meanings behind the words. I should be teaching them, passing on what was given to me. Yet, every time I try, I feel torn—my parents expect me to be present, to participate fully in our family’s way, while my children need me to guide them, to make the traditions their own.

The pressure builds inside me, a knot of guilt and longing. I want to be a good son, but I also want to be a good Jewish parent. The holiday approaches, and I am caught between the voices of my past and the needs of my future, unsure which path to follow.
